dimensional each) for a total of5·(1,432+1 ,910+1) = 16 ,715 numbers
– just above 0.6% of the original.
To measure the difference (error) betweenAand its rank-kapproxima-
tion ˆA(k), we need the notion of a norm. In Section 3.1, we already used
norms on vectors that measure the length of a vector. By analogy we can
also deﬁne norms on matrices.
Deﬁnition 4.23 (Spectral Norm of a Matrix). For x∈Rn\{0}, the spectral spectral norm
norm of a matrix A∈Rm×n is deﬁned as
∥A∥2 := max
x
∥Ax∥2
∥x∥2
